reviewText: THE SECRET AGENT CLUB (1996, 90 minutes) is a very, very sad reminder that everything must have a beginning, and you can't begin a genre omelet without breaking some eggs - or some integrity.Here the lovable Hulk Hogan (hey, one of his greatest attributes is he's nowhere near as nuts as Jesse Ventura) plays toy store owner Ray. Ray has a young son, Jeremy (Matthew McCurley) with whom he has a troublesome lack of connection. As a struggling single parent and widower, Ray has his hands full.They turn out to be even fuller still when it is revealed Ray is a master spy with an organization called SHADOW. Ray is protecting a prototype laser gun and some very nasty people want that gun. These villains are never identified at all, but they consist of some very goofy people including Lesley-Anne Down, Barry Bostwick and Richard Moll. Rounding out this odd cast are a few of little Jeremy's pals and the great immortal James Hong as Ray's partner Mr. Yamamoto (sometimes erroneously credited as "Mr. Yamata").Well, this movie, though aimed at little kids, is even worse than you can possibly imagine. As I often am forced to say, it seems as if it had been written by little kids, and it staggers the mind thinking about greats like Down and Jimmy Hong starring in such a film. As for Hogan, I find his acting improving slowly but surely and for me, he's a comforting screen presence. He could almost handle a dramatic lead at this point in his life.At the time, Hogan was doing things likeSpy Hardand3 Ninjas - High Noon on Mega Mountain. Such careers as Hogan's are nothing to be sniffed at in my opinion - but it got Hogan where he is today which is the interminable chain of cameo appearances.However painfully stupid this film frankly is, it opened lots of doors. Everything fromSpy Kids(2001 and the resulting franchise) andAgent Cody Banks(2003 plus sequel) all the way to Jackie Chan's charming contributionThe Spy Next Door(2010, see my review) - it all resulted directly from this silly film.A final word of warning: there is a great deal of violence here that in my view is completely inappropriate and unhealthy for small children - who are allegedly the target audience. Be warned, too, that because of the time period and this film's budget, it'll be worse than any crap from the 1980s. Indeed, this film actually looks like genuine 1980s crap.
Title: N/A

reviewText: "The Secret Agent Club" is probably one of Hulk Hogan's better vehicles.  Well... at least it's a major imrovement over "Santa With Muscles".The plot is straight foward enough.  Hogan plays a secret agent who steals a prototype laser gun away from some bad guys(played hammily by Lesley Ann Down and Richard Moll).  Back at home, Hogan(whose own son doesn't know what he really does for a living) has his cover blown when he is kidnapped by the bad guys.  The gun falls into the hands of the son who hatches a plan to rescue his dad with the help of his young friends.Pretty typical family action film, mainly notable for the fact that it predates the similarly themed(and far more successful) "Spy Kids".  It has a few slow stretches, but overall "The Secret Agent Club" is a movie the kids will like... and the parents can tolerate.
summary: Another Family Friendly Flick from the Hulkster

reviewText: The people who ghost-wrote my brief but captivating autobiograohy (I can tell you no more other than "The Zeek is coming!"), told me that I believe the Hulk Hogan movies are all "Masterpieces!", and that they are my only love that rivals the love of my "American Heroes 2" DVD, a love that truly knows no bounds. So it follows that I love this movie, even though I watched it about five years ago, and distinctly remember not being entertained by it (McCinsey's Island on the other hand... now there's a movie!). However, my autobio says I love all of Mr. Hogan's movies (I certainly _do_ love the artiste who produces them), and so I must accordingly give this five stars.

reviewText: I received this as a Christmas present. I thought this movie was alright, but it's nowhere near as good as 'Suburban Commando' Hulk Hogan plays a dad named Ray Chase. Ray is a Secret Agent to stops terrorists, but to his son, he is a nerdy toy salesman. When Ray is kidnapped, his son Jeremy and his friends form a plan and save Ray from a guns dealer. I'd probably recommend SECRET AGENT CLUB!!!
